summary: This document is an email chain from July 2023 between attorney Jeanne M. Christensen and an unnamed recipient at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. The emails discuss a follow-up regarding Leon Black, referencing his $62.5 million settlement with the US Virgin Islands and allegations of sexual assault, and attempt to schedule a call to discuss the matter.

persons.name: Jeanne M. Christensen
persons.context: Attorney who initiated the email chain to follow up on Leon Black, referencing his settlement and allegations of sexual assault, and attempting to schedule a call with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Identified as having paid $62.5 million to the US Virgin Islands and being accused of sexual assault by multiple women, according to the email. The correspondence urges the U.S. Attorney's Office to investigate.

connections.description: Christensen is an attorney referencing Black's legal and financial settlements and allegations, suggesting she may be representing or advocating for parties with claims against him.

events.title: Leon Black settles with US Virgin Islands
events.description: Referenced via a Reuters article link, stating Leon Black settled with the US Virgin Islands for $62.5 million over Epstein-related matters.

events.title: Email correspondence regarding Leon Black follow-up
events.description: Attorney Jeanne M. Christensen emails the U.S. Attorney's Office to follow up on Leon Black, citing his settlement and new allegations, and attempts to schedule a call.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Attorney Jeanne M. Christensen contacted the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York in July 2023 regarding a follow-up on Leon Black.
The email references that Leon Black paid $62.5 million to the US Virgin Islands, not including payments to individual women.
The email states allegations that Leon Black sexually assaulted multiple women, with one lawyer reportedly representing ten such women.
The correspondence criticizes the lack of criminal charges against Leon Black and urges the U.S. Attorney's Office to investigate based on this information.
The recipient's name in the email chain is redacted, but they are identified as being from the Civil Rights Unit of the SDNY handling trafficking matters.
